snippet.textDisplay: So Carlos Ghosn was on probation awaiting trial later this year, until he ESCAPED TOKYO BY BULLET TRAIN AND FLEW TO LEBANON. He’ll be holding a press conference on Wednesday to “explain his side of the story.”
snippet.textOriginal: So Carlos Ghosn was on probation awaiting trial later this year, until he ESCAPED TOKYO BY BULLET TRAIN AND FLEW TO LEBANON. He’ll be holding a press conference on Wednesday to “explain his side of the story.”

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting take on Nissan.  I agree with the quality not being what it once was and that it's Asian competitors still are however, I do know that Nissan lost it's way in the 80's with "boring" cars and the Altima has always been one of their top sellers.  Because of that, the Altima should be one of the BEST quality cars on the market today but it's not because of reasons you sited.  Nissan seems to be trying to play it safe by replicating the look of one car to it's whole line rather than differentiating models.   I own a Rogue and it is a good car.  The weak spot is not necessarily the CVT but a combination of a weak engine and the updated CVT that was done to try and mimic a traditional transmission.  Remember, when Nissan introduced the CVT most if not all of it's line beat all competitors in MPG and that was a selling point.  Since then everyone has caught up to them with newer, more reliable transmissions.  I hope Nissan can turn itself around in the near future.   Oh and another car manufacturer that "should" have the best quality but doesn't...Jeep.  Jeep has been making the same body style for so long, it should lead the industry in reliability.   Nissan is not alone in the struggle for quality.  Wait a minute, Nissan/Renault, Chrysler/Fiat, could it be the other guys????
snippet.textOriginal: Interesting take on Nissan.  I agree with the quality not being what it once was and that it's Asian competitors still are however, I do know that Nissan lost it's way in the 80's with "boring" cars and the Altima has always been one of their top sellers.  Because of that, the Altima should be one of the BEST quality cars on the market today but it's not because of reasons you sited.  Nissan seems to be trying to play it safe by replicating the look of one car to it's whole line rather than differentiating models.   I own a Rogue and it is a good car.  The weak spot is not necessarily the CVT but a combination of a weak engine and the updated CVT that was done to try and mimic a traditional transmission.  Remember, when Nissan introduced the CVT most if not all of it's line beat all competitors in MPG and that was a selling point.  Since then everyone has caught up to them with newer, more reliable transmissions.  I hope Nissan can turn itself around in the near future.   Oh and another car manufacturer that "should" have the best quality but doesn't...Jeep.  Jeep has been making the same body style for so long, it should lead the industry in reliability.   Nissan is not alone in the struggle for quality.  Wait a minute, Nissan/Renault, Chrysler/Fiat, could it be the other guys????

snippet.textDisplay:
"Find their audience and cater to them " is a super hollow piece of advice. It's like telling a basketball play they need to score points. As cool as an S16/Z35/R36 would be, that won't save Nissan at all, the sportscar market is tiny.

They need to pull a page from the Porsche playbook with quality vehicles that can sell at volume (Cayenne) and MAYBE when they turn around invest in a new sportscar platform.
snippet.textOriginal:
"Find their audience and cater to them " is a super hollow piece of advice. It's like telling a basketball play they need to score points. As cool as an S16/Z35/R36 would be, that won't save Nissan at all, the sportscar market is tiny.

They need to pull a page from the Porsche playbook with quality vehicles that can sell at volume (Cayenne) and MAYBE when they turn around invest in a new sportscar platform.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nissan actually makes more reliable cars than honda and
toyota. The herd sheep just follow along their media overlords that are
obviously biased. Nissan's model line is old but the new product coming
through and are industry leaders (their designs have been copied so much
and now toyota wants to add awd to the camry). Altima sales were up 16%
and neck and neck with the accord for December but donut "forgot" to
mention that in their video. IF the plan is to cut incentives and fix
brand image then Nissan will be fine. They also need a good publicists
to combat the constant bias and one-sided stories coming out of the
media allover. Truth be told, sales were only down 9% for the year with
old models and cuts to incentives and fleet sales. That's not that bad
at all.

snippet.textDisplay: I owned an '04 Altima 2.5S for 4 years from 2014-2018. It had aspirations of awesomeness, I loved the styling, I loved the power (compared to other cars of this era). It was a manual and had one of the lowest 5th gears I have ever rode with. I could drive up many grades without having to downshift and I still got 29-32mpg. Then... in 2016, it all went to hell in a hand basket. First, the catalytic converter started to act up and after reading the horror stories of other owners I opted to replace that ASAP. While underneath the car I noticed another demon these cars possess, rust... Both floor boards on the passenger and driver side were almost totally rusted out. Later that year I fabbed some replacement panels before after market replacement panels were as readily available as they are today. Then, the one that took the cake, I started to fear that the head gasket was starting to give out when a bunch of random codes started popping up. At this point I decided to cut my losses. Sold it and got a Toyota, will never look back, and will never buy another Nissan ever again.
snippet.textOriginal: I owned an '04 Altima 2.5S for 4 years from 2014-2018. It had aspirations of awesomeness, I loved the styling, I loved the power (compared to other cars of this era). It was a manual and had one of the lowest 5th gears I have ever rode with. I could drive up many grades without having to downshift and I still got 29-32mpg. Then... in 2016, it all went to hell in a hand basket. First, the catalytic converter started to act up and after reading the horror stories of other owners I opted to replace that ASAP. While underneath the car I noticed another demon these cars possess, rust... Both floor boards on the passenger and driver side were almost totally rusted out. Later that year I fabbed some replacement panels before after market replacement panels were as readily available as they are today. Then, the one that took the cake, I started to fear that the head gasket was starting to give out when a bunch of random codes started popping up. At this point I decided to cut my losses. Sold it and got a Toyota, will never look back, and will never buy another Nissan ever again.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly does a corporation that refuses to understand such simple business concepts as "know your market" even deserve to survive? The Nissan we loved is long dead and was unsustainable anyway. Ghosn put the final nail in the coffin by torpedoing quality, laying off all the labor, stealing the money, and running away to Lebanon like the little shrew-faced shitbag he is.

My prediction? The current generation of Z and GT-R are the last, and we'll likely never see a new "real" performance model from them again. Nissan can no longer afford to produce them, and the performance versions of their late "bread and butter" cars are bland, underpowered, and usually stupid. Juke NISMO was simply an asinine concept that never should have made it out of the product development meeting, and Sentra NISMO is such a poser they couldn't even bring themselves to properly call it an "SE-R". What should have been a big high five to the spocom fans was more like a kick in the farthorn and a middle finger.
snippet.textOriginal:
Honestly does a corporation that refuses to understand such simple business concepts as "know your market" even deserve to survive? The Nissan we loved is long dead and was unsustainable anyway. Ghosn put the final nail in the coffin by torpedoing quality, laying off all the labor, stealing the money, and running away to Lebanon like the little shrew-faced shitbag he is. 

My prediction? The current generation of Z and GT-R are the last, and we'll likely never see a new "real" performance model from them again. Nissan can no longer afford to produce them, and the performance versions of their late "bread and butter" cars are bland, underpowered, and usually stupid. Juke NISMO was simply an asinine concept that never should have made it out of the product development meeting, and Sentra NISMO is such a poser they couldn't even bring themselves to properly call it an "SE-R". What should have been a big high five to the spocom fans was more like a kick in the farthorn and a middle finger.

snippet.textDisplay:
As much as i like the idea of bringing back the S chassis, its a bad idea they're at the brink of collapse and developing a car isnt exactly cheap. Purist jdm fan boys would complain the same way they did with the gt86 and the supra because collaboration with another brand is pretty much the cheapest way they can do it and with renault as the most likely option i doubt it will work.

Im not an expert but for me they should be challenging and try to be better than the toyota reliability the same way the koreans did, and please continue on making the GTR better its already on the same price point as a porsche 911.

snippet.textDisplay: Awwwww. The infamous plastic timing chain guides! I remember working on those.  the CVTs are still garbage till this day.  Most of their cars might have been  boring by the late 90's but they were still exceptional in reliability and build quality.  I was shocked when the Renault merger happened. That's when it came out that Nissan was on the verge of going under. It amazes me that they even brought the R34 Skyline to the market at a time when they were on their last leg!

snippet.textDisplay:
Nissan is making the mistake Toyota made when Toyota got rid of it's sports lines and focused on practicality. The GTR has not changed much since it's come out and the 370z is in need of a serious update (commented before watching video and see this was mentioned). Outside of those vehicles, Nissan has a cookie cutter line up...the Maxima and Murano are decent, the new Pathfinder looks terrible, the Armada is so-so, the Titan...whew..and the rest of the line...yawn/snore (Kicks, Versa, Rogue, Altima)...I know, you just threw up in your mouth a little...


Nissan has good cars in its portfoliio...they need to get past the "volume" car mind state.... they need to revise the 240 and bring it back as an entry level mid tier performance model, dare I say the 200...but if they do it right, it could be a viable performance low end entry level model to replace the Versa, the Silvia would be awesome, I mean.... they need a lifeline and something with a pulse...at some point, letting accountants run your business yields stale "practical" results...they need to find a blend.
snippet.textOriginal:
Nissan is making the mistake Toyota made when Toyota got rid of it's sports lines and focused on practicality.  The GTR has not changed much since it's come out and the 370z is in need of a serious update (commented before watching video and see this was mentioned).  Outside of those vehicles, Nissan has a cookie cutter line up...the Maxima and Murano are decent, the new Pathfinder looks terrible, the Armada is so-so, the Titan...whew..and the rest of the line...yawn/snore (Kicks, Versa, Rogue, Altima)...I know, you just threw up in your mouth a little...   


Nissan has good cars in its portfoliio...they need to get past the "volume" car mind state.... they need to revise the 240 and bring it back as an entry level mid tier performance model, dare I say the 200...but if they do it right, it could be a viable performance low end entry level model to replace the Versa, the Silvia would be awesome, I mean.... they need a lifeline and something with a pulse...at some point, letting accountants run  your business yields stale "practical" results...they need to find a blend.

snippet.textDisplay:
Plastic guides for timing CHAINS.

Honestly I don't know any manufacturers that use anything different. Maybe the grade of plastic is lower? Shit even the KA motors in 240sx, 90s altimas and hard body trucks had plastic timing chain guides. I just replaced the chain and guides in my 98 Altima a few months ago. At 220k miles and it was not well maintained...

But Nissan was pushing for chains to reduce maintenance costs. I don't think if they had timing belts that anyone would ever change them on time anyway. Honestly if people could just change their oil often enough and keep it full it really wouldn't be an issue. ...VQs have oil filter housing o rings blow out that causes loss of oil that causes timing chains to go. So truly its not just the plastic guides.

But I still wouldn't recommend any CVT Nissan. And they do rust faster than most other cars.
snippet.textOriginal:
Plastic guides for timing CHAINS. 

Honestly I don't know any manufacturers that use anything different. Maybe the grade of plastic is lower? Shit even the KA motors in 240sx, 90s altimas and hard body trucks had plastic timing chain guides. I just replaced the chain and guides in my 98 Altima a few months ago. At 220k miles and it was not well maintained...

But Nissan was pushing for chains to reduce maintenance costs. I don't think if they had timing belts that anyone would ever change them on time anyway.  Honestly if people could just change their oil often enough and keep it full it really wouldn't be an issue.  ...VQs have oil filter housing o rings blow out that causes loss of oil that causes timing chains to go. So truly its not just the plastic guides. 

But I still wouldn't recommend any CVT Nissan. And they do rust faster than most other cars.

snippet.textDisplay:
Saying that Nissan needs to FOCUS on the Z and GT-R as part of their revival plan is a short-sighted, car nerd viewpoint. Yes they need to update the Z but doing a PROPER follow-up (note I said proper, since it needs to be an amazing car to live up to the legacy) to the GT-R will cost a ton of money that needs to go elsewhere for now. The Z is cheaper and a bigger volume seller so making a new one fits into any proper plan to revive Nissan - and Nissan is supposedly doing exactly that already. The GT-R though can wait (and that's coming from someone who owns three generations of them including the last two). Besides, a few year's hiatus will just let the anticipation for a new GT-R build back up.


For proper sustainable growth Nissan needs to crib from its own playbook - focus on mass-market cars with a touch of performance to them that distinguishes them from the pack, just like they did in the 90s. With the new, much better 2020 Sentra out it's time to do a proper SE-R follow-on. Keep selling crossovers but make them fun and not generic - the new 2020 Juke is a perfect example vis-a-vis the lame Kicks (too bad Nissan isn't bringing the new Juke here yet). Make proper Nismo versions, not badge jobs. Put AWD and a good automatic in the Maxima to bring back the 4DSC cred. Oh, and make a good crossover EV for that green demographic. Nissan doesn't need one really expensive halo car like the current R35, its heritage and former identity was based on having solid regular cars with aspirational models to inspire people to keep the faith.


None of this is really all that hard. It's basically the playbook that brought Chrysler back from the brink - with the addition of the EV stuff. The thing that would suck most is if Nissan can't pull of something Chrysler of all companies was able to do.
snippet.textOriginal:
Saying that Nissan needs to FOCUS on the Z and GT-R as part of their revival plan is a short-sighted, car nerd viewpoint. Yes they need to update the Z but doing a PROPER follow-up (note I said proper, since it needs to be an amazing car to live up to the legacy) to the GT-R will cost a ton of money that needs to go elsewhere for now. The Z is cheaper and a bigger volume seller so making a new one fits into any proper plan to revive Nissan - and Nissan is supposedly doing exactly that already. The GT-R though can wait (and that's coming from someone who owns three generations of them including the last two). Besides, a few year's hiatus will just let the anticipation for a new GT-R build back up.


For proper sustainable growth Nissan needs to crib from its own playbook - focus on mass-market cars with a touch of performance to them that distinguishes them from the pack, just like they did in the 90s. With the new, much better 2020 Sentra out it's time to do a proper SE-R follow-on. Keep selling crossovers but make them fun and not generic - the new 2020 Juke is a perfect example vis-a-vis the lame Kicks (too bad Nissan isn't bringing the new Juke here yet). Make proper Nismo versions, not badge jobs. Put AWD and a good automatic in the Maxima to bring back the 4DSC cred.  Oh, and make a good crossover EV for that green demographic. Nissan doesn't need one really expensive halo car like the current R35, its heritage and former identity was based on having solid regular cars with aspirational models to inspire people to keep the faith.


None of this is really all that hard. It's basically the playbook that brought Chrysler back from the brink - with the addition of the EV stuff. The thing that would suck most is if Nissan can't pull of something Chrysler of all companies was able to do.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a big time Nissan fan. Wouldn't drive anything else until I bought the new Titan XD and Altima. The Titan gas engine is solid, but the paint was cheap, the interior was cheap, sound system was trash and the transmission was a mess. The Altima value dropped almost 70% in three years. Never again will I buy a Nissan car other than a GTR. They've seriously lost all of their 90s mojo.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a big time Nissan fan. Wouldn't drive anything else until I bought the new Titan XD and Altima. The Titan gas engine is solid, but the paint was cheap, the interior was cheap, sound system was trash and the transmission was a mess. The Altima value dropped almost 70% in three years. Never again will I buy a Nissan car other than a GTR. They've seriously lost all of their 90s mojo.

snippet.textDisplay:
Japan, somewhere in Nissan Headquarters:


- Dammit! After that gaijin and his "Antonio Banderas and his Totallynotafake Christmas Orchestra" our company is disHONORed!!!
- What are we gonna do???
- There's only one thing!
- What thing?
- This is totally "out of the box" idea but how about a crossover... but it's be EV with coupe styling!
- Oh, and let's call him GT-R!
- Yeah, and let's make him like GT-R styling too!
- Wait, wait, wait... arent we be copying someone with "F"?
- Nope, no one... what's honor for todays anyway?

snippet.textDisplay: Its called a timing chain not belt.  Also nearly all car chain guides are made from plastic.  Nissan just happened to use a cheaper quality of plastic thats why they wore faster than higher quality versions in later years.  Those vehicles that were affected at the time had a bulletin for free chain and guide replacement.  Nissan was practically the pioneer in cvt but there was many problems with its original design.  Even today cars that switched from a conventional trans. to a cvt trans. are failing.  Those transmission arent design to handle high load.

snippet.textDisplay:
In Europe Qashqai is the best selling CROSSOVER ever, but still it's not the car I want to have. We counted on the new Pulsar to have GTI-R version, but they don't even sell civilian verision anymore. We don't have maximas, altimas and sentras. There is no car that replaces Primera (Infiniti G20 in US). They don't even sell Patrol in EU.

Hard to say. but my firends are buying different brands, because there in nothng to choose from Nissan.

Greetings from nissanzone.pl

snippet.textDisplay:
Car guys think everyone would want an R32GTR because that’s what they want but fail to realise they’re in a slim minority. Most people don’t want perforce cars. The speed makes them frightened or they’re just some nice nurse lady who wants to use next to nothing in fuel to get to work. The idea that you can save a brand with performance cars seems misinformed to me. The future of car companies may not even be making cars at all. The world is changing (fast). Car ownership may drop and go away, population booms will see roads ever more clogged which may render personal transportation useless. Toyota is transitioning/ shifting focus to a mobility company. It just seems really boomer to be wanting Nissan to build like they used to.

I don’t see what’s wrong with letting Nissan go. There’s plenty of current day brands and models out there. Just because they build cars we liked in the 80’s and 90’d doesn’t mean we have to hang onto them. Especially since they’re a very different company from that time with differnt people.

Car ownership may drop and go away, population booms will see roads ever more clogged which may render personal transportation useless. Toyota is transitioning/ shifting focus  to a mobility company. snippet.textDisplay: If they plan on remaking any of the legendary models (gtr,fairlady,240s,300zx,sentra ser) it should only happen after new management is put into place. The quality of the vehicles right now wouldnt do any of them justice without great quality behind them. You cant just slap a iconic badge on one of these newer styles and expect it to sell because of it. Make it right in the first place and itll sell.
